    1654           0 : UnparseLanguageIndependentConstructs::unparseStatementFromTokenStreamForNodeContainingTransformation(

    4109             :        // DQ (2/18/2021): This is a bug in the token-based unparsing for test_127.cpp in the code segregation tests.
    4110             :        // The details below are copied from the top of that test code. This will need to be fixed later.
    4111             : 
    4112             :           // The bug is that the #endif is not generated in the output.
    4113             :           // The reason is because the statement before it is transformed (literally replaced)
    4114             :           // This causes the mapping to the leading tokens (before the transformed statement)
    4115             :           // to be unparsed, but the trailing whitespace after the statement can't be looked
    4116             :           // up in the map because the statement used as a key does not exist. Normally the
    4117             :           // leading whitespace of the next statement would be used, but this transformed
    4118             :           // statement is the last statement in the block.
    4119             : 
    4120             :           // Note that adding a statement after the transformed statement (so it is not the
    4121             :           // last statement in the block) allows the leading whitespace of the statement after
    4122             :           // the transformed statement to be found.
    4123             : 
    4124             :           // To fix this, it might be best to either not unparse the leading whitespace before
    4125             :           // the transformed statement, or have a secondary key that can be used to lookup the

    7210             : bool
    7211          36 : UnparseLanguageIndependentConstructs::isRequiredOperator( SgBinaryOp* binary_op, bool current_function_call_uses_operator_syntax, bool parent_function_call_uses_operator_syntax )
    7212             :    {
    7213             :   // DQ (4/14/2013): The mixing of overloaded operator names and operator syntax has been a bit complex.
    7214             :   // There are special cases that are especially troubling, so this code tries to handle this.
    7215             :   // ROSE now preserves the original form of the operator if it was used as either:
    7216             :   //    1) the overloaded operator name, e.g. "i = result.operator&()->size();", or
    7217             :   //    2) using the operator syntax, e,g, "i = (&result)->size();"
    7218             :   // There are different function resolution lookup rules for each type of representaion.
    7219             :   // So this is a subtle area of C++ to start with.  ROSE tracks in the IR (in the SgFunctionCallExp)
    7220             :   // if the function call uses the operator syntax (data member, p_uses_operator_syntax, with
    7221             :   // set and get access functions automatically generated by ROSETTA.
    7222             : 
    7223             :   // Some complex examples are:
    7224             :   //    1) "i = result.operator&()->size();" vs. "i = (&result)->size();", the use of SgArrowOp "->" is required.
    7225             :   //    2) "ref.operator->()->getFormat();" vs. "ref->getFormat();", the use of SgArrowOp "->" is supressed.
    7226             :   //    3) "s.operator&();" vs. "&s;", example of prefix operator syntax.
    7227             : 
    7228          36 :      bool returnValue = false;
    7229             : 
    7230          36 :      ASSERT_not_null(binary_op);
    7231             : 
    7232             : #if 0
    7233             :      printf ("In isRequiredOperator(binary_op = %p = %s, current_function_call_uses_operator_syntax = %s, parent_function_call_uses_operator_syntax = %s \n",

    7237             : 
    7238             : #endif
    7239             :

    7564             :        // integers which when used as function parameters lead to the wrong function resolution.
    7565             :        // We can't just output the integer conversion of the character since where this is used as a function
    7566             :        // argument it will match a different function prototype (which might not even exist) (see bug 2005_30.C).
    7567             :        // curprint ( (int) char_val->get_value();

    7569             :              {
    7570           0 :                case '\0': curprint ( "\'\\0\'"); break;
    7571           0 :                case '\1': curprint ( "\'\\1\'"); break;

    7575           0 :                case '\5': curprint ( "\'\\5\'"); break;
    7576           0 :                case '\6': curprint ( "\'\\6\'"); break;

    7578             :             // This case is replicated with ASCII BS case '\a' (below)
    7579             :             // case '\7': curprint ( "\'\\7\'"; break;
    7580             :             // This case is replicated with ASCI BEL case '\b' (below)
    7581             :             // case '\8': curprint ( "\'\\8\'"; break;
    7582             :             // This case is replicated with ASCI HT case '\t' (below)
    7583             :             // case '\9': curprint ( "\'\\9\'"; break;
    7584             :             // Note that if we skip this case then '\b' is converted to '^H' which is likely
    7585             :             // equivalant but is different enough to be annoying.  Likely other literals have
    7586             :             // similar equivalants.  I now expect that '^H' is the wrong translation of '\b'.
    7587             :             // So the cases below are required.
    7588           0 :                case '\n': curprint ( "\'\\n\'"); break;
    7589           0 :                case '\t': curprint ( "\'\\t\'"); break;
    7590           0 :                case '\v': curprint ( "\'\\v\'"); break;
    7591           0 :                case '\b': curprint ( "\'\\b\'"); break;
    7592           0 :                case '\r': curprint ( "\'\\r\'"); break;
    7593           0 :                case '\f': curprint ( "\'\\f\'"); break;
    7594           0 :                case '\a': curprint ( "\'\\a\'"); break;
    7595           0 :                case '\'': curprint ( "\'\\'\'"); break;
    7596           0 :                case '\"': curprint ( "\'\"\'"); break;

    7600           0 :                case 127: curprint ( "char(127)"); break;
    7601             :             // This case is required since "\\" is the C++ name of the ASCII "\" character
    7602           0 :                case '\\': curprint ( "\'\\\\'"); break;
    7603             : 
    7604             : #if 0

    8900           0 : void UnparseLanguageIndependentConstructs::unparseOmpWhenClause(SgOmpClause* clause, SgUnparse_Info& info) {
    8901           0 :     ROSE_ASSERT(clause != NULL);
    8902           0 :     SgOmpWhenClause * c = isSgOmpWhenClause(clause);
    8903           0 :     ROSE_ASSERT(c!= NULL);
    8904           0 :     curprint(string(" when("));
    8905           0 :     SgExpression* user_condition = c->get_user_condition();
    8906           0 :     SgExpression* score = NULL;
    8907           0 :     SgUnparse_Info ninfo(info);
    8908           0 :     bool has_trait_set = false;
    8909           0 :     if (user_condition) {
    8910           0 :         curprint(string("user={condition("));
    8911           0 :         score = c->get_user_condition_score();
    8912           0 :         if (score) {
    8913           0 :             curprint(string("score("));
    8914           0 :             unparseExpression(score, ninfo);
    8915           0 :             curprint(string("): "));
    8916             :         }
    8917           0 :         unparseExpression(user_condition, ninfo);
    8918           0 :         curprint(string(")}"));
    8919           0 :         has_trait_set = true;
    8920           0 :     };
    8921           0 :     std::list<SgStatement*> construct_directives = c->get_construct_directives();
    8922           0 :     if (construct_directives.size()) {
    8923           0 :         if (has_trait_set) {
    8924           0 :             curprint(string(", "));
    8925           0 :         };
    8926           0 :         curprint(string("construct={"));
    8927           0 :         std::list<SgStatement*>::iterator iter;
    8928           0 :         bool has_trait_selector = false;
    8929           0 :         for (iter = construct_directives.begin(); iter != construct_directives.end(); iter++) {
    8930           0 :             if (has_trait_selector) {
    8931           0 :                 curprint(string(", "));
    8932           0 :             };
    8933           0 :             isVariant = true;
    8934           0 :             isConstruct = true;
    8935           0 :             unparseOmpGenericStatement(*iter, info);
    8936           0 :             isConstruct = false;
    8937           0 :             isVariant = false;
    8938           0 :             has_trait_selector = true;
    8939           0 :         };
    8940           0 :         curprint(string("}"));
    8941           0 :         has_trait_set = true;
    8942           0 :     };
    8943           0 :     bool has_device = false;
    8944           0 :     SgExpression* device_arch = c->get_device_arch();
    8945           0 :     if (device_arch != NULL) {
    8946           0 :         if (has_trait_set) {
    8947           0 :             curprint(string(", "));
    8948           0 :         };
    8949           0 :         if (!has_device) {
    8950           0 :             curprint(string("device={"));
    8951           0 :             has_device = true;
    8952           0 :         };
    8953           0 :         curprint(string("arch("));
    8954           0 :         unparseExpression(device_arch, ninfo);
    8955           0 :         curprint(string(")"));
    8956           0 :     };
    8957           0 :     SgExpression* device_isa = c->get_device_isa();
    8958           0 :     if (device_isa != NULL) {
    8959           0 :         if (has_trait_set) {
    8960           0 :             curprint(string(", "));
    8961           0 :         };
    8962           0 :         if (!has_device) {
    8963           0 :             curprint(string("device={"));
    8964           0 :             has_device = true;
    8965           0 :         };
    8966           0 :         curprint(string("isa("));
    8967           0 :         unparseExpression(device_isa, ninfo);
    8968           0 :         curprint(string(")"));
    8969           0 :     };
    8970           0 :     SgOmpClause::omp_when_context_kind_enum device_kind = c->get_device_kind();
    8971           0 :     if (device_kind != SgOmpClause::e_omp_when_context_kind_unknown) {
    8972           0 :         if (has_trait_set) {
    8973           0 :             curprint(string(", "));
    8974           0 :         };
    8975           0 :         if (!has_device) {
    8976           0 :             curprint(string("device={"));
    8977           0 :             has_device = true;
    8978           0 :         };

   10942         109 : void UnparseLanguageIndependentConstructs::unparseOmpExpressionClause(SgOmpClause* clause, SgUnparse_Info& info)
   10943             : {
   10944         109 :   ASSERT_not_null(clause);
   10945         109 :   SgOmpExpressionClause * c = isSgOmpExpressionClause (clause);
   10946         109 :   ROSE_ASSERT  (c);
   10947         109 :   SgOmpExpressionClause* exp_clause = isSgOmpExpressionClause(c);
   10948         109 :   ROSE_ASSERT(exp_clause);
   10949             : 
   10950             : 
   10951             :   // ordered (n) vs ordered : (n) is optional
   10952         109 :   if (isSgOmpOrderedClause(c) && (exp_clause->get_expression() == NULL))
   10953             :   {
   10954           9 :     curprint(string(" ordered"));
   10955           9 :     return;
   10956             :   }
   10957             : 
   10958         100 :   if (isSgOmpCollapseClause(c))
   10959          22 :     curprint(string(" collapse("));
   10960          89 :   else if (isSgOmpIfClause(c)) {
   10961          37 :     curprint(string(" if("));
   10962          37 :     if (isSgOmpIfClause(c)->get_modifier() == SgOmpClause::e_omp_if_parallel) {
   10963           2 :         curprint(string("parallel : "));
   10964             :     }
   10965          37 :     if (isSgOmpIfClause(c)->get_modifier() == SgOmpClause::e_omp_if_simd) {
   10966           2 :         curprint(string("simd : "));
   10967             :     }
   10968          37 :     if (isSgOmpIfClause(c)->get_modifier() == SgOmpClause::e_omp_if_taskloop) {
   10969           0 :         curprint(string("taskloop : "));

   11400             : //! This is not intended to be directly called anytime.

   11402           0 : void UnparseLanguageIndependentConstructs::unparseOmpPrefix(SgUnparse_Info& info)

   11408             : // simple directives: atomic, section, taskwait, barrier
   11409          46 : void UnparseLanguageIndependentConstructs::unparseOmpSimpleStatement(SgStatement * stmt,  SgUnparse_Info& info)

   11415          46 :   if (b_stmt)
   11416             :   {
   11417          29 :     ROSE_ASSERT (stmt->variantT() == V_SgOmpSectionStatement);

   11423             : //----- refactor unparsing for threadprivate and flush ???
   11424           9 : void UnparseLanguageIndependentConstructs::unparseOmpFlushStatement(SgStatement* stmt, SgUnparse_Info& info)
   11425             : {
   11426           9 :   ASSERT_not_null(stmt);
   11427           9 :   SgOmpFlushStatement * s = isSgOmpFlushStatement(stmt);
   11428           9 :   ASSERT_not_null(s);
   11429             : 
   11430           9 :   unparseOmpDirectivePrefixAndName(stmt, info);
   11431           9 :   if (s->get_clauses().size()!=0) { unparseOmpBeginDirectiveClauses(stmt, info); }
   11432           9 :   if (s->get_variables().size()>0)
   11433          14 :     curprint(string ("("));
   11434             :   //unparse variable list then
   11435           9 :   SgVarRefExpPtrList::iterator p = s->get_variables().begin();
   11436          22 :   while ( p != s->get_variables().end() )
   11437             :   {
   11438          13 :     ASSERT_not_null((*p)->get_symbol());
   11439          13 :     SgInitializedName* init_name = (*p)->get_symbol()->get_declaration();
   11440          13 :     ASSERT_not_null(init_name);
   11441          26 :     SgName tmp_name  = init_name->get_name();
   11442          13 :     curprint( tmp_name.str());
   11443             : 
   11444             :     // Move to the next argument
   11445          13 :     p++;
   11446             : 
   11447             :     // Check if this is the last argument (output a "," separator if not)
   11448          13 :     if (p != s->get_variables().end())
   11449             :     {
   11450          12 :       curprint( ",");
   11451             :     }
   11452             :   }
   11453           9 :   if (s->get_variables().size()>0)
   11454          14 :     curprint (string (")"));
   11455           9 :   unp->u_sage->curprint_newline();

   11920             : // This is a catch-all helper function
   11921         732 : void UnparseLanguageIndependentConstructs::unparseOmpGenericStatement (SgStatement* stmt,     SgUnparse_Info& info)
   11922             : {
   11923         732 :   ASSERT_not_null(stmt);
   11924             :   // unparse the begin directive
   11925         732 :   unparseOmpDirectivePrefixAndName (stmt, info);
   11926             :   // unparse the parentheses of construct directive
   11927         732 :   if (isConstruct) {
   11928           0 :     curprint(string ("("));
   11929         732 :   };
   11930             :   // unparse the begin directive's clauses
   11931         732 :   unparseOmpBeginDirectiveClauses(stmt, info);
   11932             :   // unparse the parentheses of construct directive
   11933         732 :   if (isConstruct) {
   11934           0 :     curprint(string (")"));
   11935         732 :   };
   11936         732 :   if (!isVariant) {
   11937         732 :     unp->u_sage->curprint_newline();
   11938         732 :   };
   11939             :   // unparse the body, if exists.
   11940         732 :   SgUpirBodyStatement* b_stmt = isSgUpirBodyStatement(stmt);
   11941         732 :   if (!isVariant && b_stmt)
   11942             :   {
   11943        1374 :     SgUnparse_Info ninfo(info);
   11944         687 :     unparseStatement(b_stmt->get_body(), ninfo);
   11945             :   }
   11946             :   else
   11947             :  {
   11948             :    //TODO assertion for must-have bodies
   11949             :   }
   11950             : 
   11951             :   // unparse the end directive and name
   11952         732 :   unparseOmpEndDirectivePrefixAndName (stmt, info);

   11954         732 :   unparseOmpEndDirectiveClauses(stmt, info);

   11957             : 
   11958             : 
   11959             : PrecedenceSpecifier
   11960       13469 : UnparseLanguageIndependentConstructs::getPrecedence(SgExpression* expr)
   11961             :    {
   11962             :   // DQ (11/24/2007): This is a redundant mechanism for computing the precedence of expressions (NO!)
   11963             :   // DQ (4/20/2013): Actually, this is the support for operator precedence that is correctly handling
   11964             :   // overloaded operators to be the precedence of the operators that they are overloading, so this
   11965             :   // is an important part of the unparser infrastructure.  There is also a specifictaion of
   11966             :   // operator precedence a static data members on each expression IR node, and this function could
   11967             :   // and likely should use the values that are set there to avoud some level of redundancy.
   11968             : 
   11969             :   // DQ (2/5/2015): Added note from google search for precedence of the noexcept operator.
   11970             :   // The standard itself doesn't specify precedence levels. They are derived from the grammar.
   11971             :   // const_cast, static_cast, dynamic_cast, reinterpret_cast, typeid, sizeof..., noexcept and
   11972             :   // alignof are not included since they are never ambiguous.
   11973             : 
   11974             : #if PRINT_DEVELOPER_WARNINGS
   11975             :      printf ("This is a redundant mechanism for computing the precedence of expressions \n");
   11976             : #endif
   11977             : 
   11978             : #if 0
   11979             :      printf ("In getPrecedence(): expr = %p = %s \n",expr,expr->class_name().c_str());
   11980             : #endif
   11981             : 
   11982             :   // This call to GetOperatorVariant will map overloaded operators for syntax (e.g. operator+())
   11983             :   // to the associated operators (e.g. +) so that the overloaded operators will have the same

   12443             : AssociativitySpecifier
   12444        1686 : UnparseLanguageIndependentConstructs::getAssociativity(SgExpression* expr)
   12445             :    {
   12446             :   // DQ (7/23/2013): This should match the table in: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operators_in_C_and_C%2B%2B#Operator_precedence
   12447             :   // Note also that this table has the precedence in the wrong order compared to how we have listed it in ROSE.
   12448             : 
   12449             :   // I have added the case for SgCastExp, but noticed that there appear to be many incorrect entries for associativity for the
   12450             :   // other operators.  This function is called in the evaluation for added "()" using the operator precedence (obtained from
   12451             :   // the function: getPrecedence()).
   12452             : 
   12453             :   // DQ (9/25/2013): It is an additional issue that some associativity rules are language dependent.  For example, I understand
   12454             :   // that Fortran supports A - B - C as A - (B - C) (right associative) where as C and C++ would treat it as (A - B) - C (left
   12455             :   // associative).  Currently all associativity is defined in terms of C/C++, this is something to fix for the Fortran.  In
   12456             :   // general we add parenthesis to support the explict handling wherever possible (I think). As a rule, Fortran relational
   12457             :   // operators are not associative.  The exponentiation operator associates right to left (right associative).  Thus, A**B**C
   12458             :   // is equal to A**(B**C) rather than (A**B)**C. All other FORTRAN operators are left to right associative (left associative)
   12459             :   // (however it appears to contradict the stated rule for minus (above).
   12460             : 
   12461             :   // DQ (4/20/2018): Added assertion.
   12462        1686 :      ASSERT_not_null(expr);
   12463             : 
   12464        1686 :      int variant = GetOperatorVariant(expr);
   12465             :
